docTitle.titlePart:
Hypomethylation of the interferon-y gene
correlates with its expression by primary T-lineage
cells *

front.div:
To determine the potential role of methylation in the regulation of interferon-y
(IFN-y) gene transcription by T cells, primary T-lineage cell populations were
analyzed for the extent of methylation of three CpG sites within or near
transcriptional activator elements in the 5' flank and first intron of the human
IFN-y gene. A striking correlation was observed between the capacity of the
IFN-y gene to be expressed and the degree of hypomethylation. The IFN-y gene
was virtually completely methylated at all sites in thymocytes, neonatal T cells,
and adult CD45RAhiCD45R010 (antigenically naive) CD4 T cells, cell types that
all have a low or undetectable capacity to express the IFN-y gene. In contrast,
there was substantial hypomethylation in T-lineage cell types with relatively high
capacities to express the IFN-y gene, including adult CD8 Tcells and adult
CD45RA10CD45ROhi (memory/effector) CD4 T cells. These results suggest that
hypomethylation of the IFN-y genetic locus may be an important determinant of
IFN-y gene expression in vivo by T-lineage cells.
